description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 1, 2020.
content: “The garment factory helped me and my family to get out of poverty. But the coronavirus has pushed me back in.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charu Suri
title: Street Art Confronts the Pandemic
description: From Norway to Colorado, street artists depict a world of masks and hand-washing (and toilet paper). One recurrent theme: a deep appreciation of health care workers.
content: Street art is the ultimate visual source of social commentary and the pandemic has lit a fire under the feet of muralists around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Introducing Rhubarb Bars, Lemon Bars’ Pinker Cousins
description: With a crunchy shortbread crust and tangy curd filling, this rhubarb-filled confection is perfect for spring.

title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Their Met Gala, Their Way. You’re Invited.’

content: Featured Article: “Their Met Gala, Their Way. You’re Invited.” by Vanessa Friedman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: The Business of Burps: Scientists Smell Profit in Cow Emissions
description: Cattle produce more methane than many large countries. A solution could be an ecological and financial breakthrough — and a Swiss biotech company may be on the cusp.
content: LANCASTER, England — Peaches, a brown-and-white Jersey cow weighing 1,200 pounds, was amiably following Edward Towers through a barn on a sunny March morning when the 6-year-old dug in her front hooves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choire Sicha
title: Now Is the Time to Learn to Play Bridge
description: It’s easier to pick up the world’s best card game at home on your own.
content: Bridge will reward you early on — but the first few hours are utterly disorienting. Using a combination of apps, books and computer players who won’t berate you for mistakes is the easiest way to power through that vicious learning curve into the fun part.

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: The Best Part of the Campaign Trail (the Food!) Comes Home
description: By ordering in, a political reporter continues to enjoy his favorite dishes from the around the country.
content: It started on my birthday. I received, on the same blessed day in April, a package of ribs from the Memphis restaurant Central BBQ, courtesy of my brother and sister-in-law, and a box of Eastern North Carolina barbecue and hush puppies from Kings BBQ Restaurant, by way of my parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Lampert
title: Fertility Clinics Stay Open Despite Unclear Guidelines
description: Many providers have continued seeing patients through the pandemic, forcing them to choose between clients and staff safety.
content: Since March, fertility clinics across the country have halted treatments for tens of thousands of people because of Covid-19, forcing patients to suspend their family planning. In recent days, some clinics have reopened, resuming services and procedures despite ongoing coronavirus concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How ‘All Day and a Night’ Dazzles With a Street Scene
description: Joe Robert Cole, the writer and director of a new Oakland-set Netflix drama discusses a high-energy sequence that takes place at a party-car-stunt display called a sideshow.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series each Friday. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: ‘All Day and a Night’ | Anatomy of a Scene

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Celebrate the end of the week with a cocktail, if that’s your speed, and the beginning of the weekend with pancakes or waffles.
content: Good morning. The mailbag’s been interesting these days, missives from all over the world, from up and down the socio-economic ladder: people eating rillettes in the Alps and canned beans in rural Maine; front-line medical workers craving fresh strawberries, unemployed car salesmen grilling pork ribs and wondering what’s going to happen next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Lanny’ and ‘The Unwinding of the Miracle’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: LOST AND WANTED, by Nell Freudenberger. (Vintage, 336 pp., $16.95.) In this ghost story in which scientific metaphors abound, a physics professor is haunted by the death of a close friend whom she never truly knew. “The effect is beautiful,” wrote our reviewer, Louisa Hall, evoking the gravitational pull of dormant, unobservable attachments and discarded hopes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: What Rights Do Pregnant Workers Have in a Pandemic?
description: Here’s how to ask for accommodations.
content: In the middle of March, when it was clear coronavirus shutdowns were imminent, Anna, 29, was at her obstetrician’s office for a pregnancy well visit. She was supposed to travel from her home in the Midwest to Florida that weekend to see her in-laws, but her doctor advised against it. Anna’s obstetrician also recommended that she work from home going forward — pregnant women’s immune systems are already taxed, and experts can’t say with certainty how the coronavirus might affect them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Find a Vaccine. Next: Produce 300 Million Vials of It.
description: Scaling up the manufacturing of syringes and other medical products required to deliver a vaccine to millions of Americans will be just as important as the vaccine itself.
content: In the midst of national shortages of testing swabs and protective gear, some medical suppliers and health policy experts are looking ahead to another extraordinary demand on manufacturing: Delivering a vaccine that could potentially end the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Porches, Yards, Driveways, Parking Lots: Where the Neighborhood Is Now
description: How we come together when we can’t go very far.
content: We walk the dogs across the meadow in the rain. We don’t talk much. We say the same things over and over, and yet somehow there’s comfort in the repetition. Yesterday someone wrote on the town listserv that certain dog owners had been spotted in the meadow less than six feet away from each other. Suddenly, everybody’s a cop, yardsticks in their minds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Hollywood’ Offers Alternate History, and Glimpses of a Real One
description: Ryan Murphy’s new period melodrama, debuting Friday on Netflix, uses real figures from the past to tell an invented history of 1940s Hollywood.
content: “Let me guess,” Patti LuPone says as she plinks olives into a martini. “You came here to be a movie star.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By JoAnna Klein
title: Your Chicken Is No Longer Pink. That Doesn’t Mean It’s Safe to Eat.
description: Next time you cook chicken, don’t rely on the color of the meat to tell you if it’s cooked enough to avoid food poisoning.
content: As we wait out this pandemic, chances are you’re at home, cooking. Perhaps you’ve baked a million loaves of bread and your sourdough starter is overflowing. If Google Trends is any indication of what comes next, after “banana bread” and “pancakes,” people are seeking “chicken recipes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Draper
title: How the N.R.A. Became ‘the Most Feared Lobbying Force in America’
description: Frank Smyth’s unauthorized history tracks the evolution of a gentlemen’s hunting club into a behemoth of Second Amendment absolutism.
content: THE N.R.A. The Unauthorized HistoryBy Frank Smyth Read by the author
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Kevin Roose
title: Doctor Who Promoted Malarial Drug Draws Scrutiny of Federal Prosectors
description: In an interview, Dr. Vladimir Zelenko said he was guilty of nothing more than sloppy wording.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal prosecutor has opened a preliminary inquiry into whether an obscure New York doctor who won White House attention by claiming he could treat the coronavirus broke the law by falsely claiming that a hospital study of drugs he had promoted had won federal approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Craig
title: The Courage to Be Alone
description: On our daily walks together, my young daughter and I begin to navigate a new reality.
content: My youngest daughter has told me that Annabelle, her baby doll, might have the coronavirus. We talk about it as we take a daily walk up the road. She’s not sure yet whether it is diabetes or the virus. Annabelle’s symptoms vary, but she has not left the small cradle by the side of my daughter’s bed in days. I have been told I can babysit for Annabelle, but only if I promise to hold her gently and not give her candy. My daughter holds my hand as we walk. She wants to talk about her doll’s sickness every day. Not surprisingly, she’s not sure when or if Annabelle will get a test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Colleges Won’t Refund Tuition. Autumn May Force a Reckoning.
description: Educators at schools from Brown to Northern Arizona know the experience is lacking. So why won’t they give some money back?
content: If you didn’t get what you paid for, and the thing you bought cost five figures, it stands to reason that you’d get some of your money back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Big Tech’s Worries Should Worry You
description: When the most successful companies are anxious, you know we’re in scary times.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Abbott
title: ‘The Streets Look So Empty’: How a Child Killer Haunted My First Novel
description: The still-unsolved Oakland County Child Killer case lodged in the author Megan Abbott’s psyche, even if she didn’t know it at the time.
content: This article is part of The New York Times True Crime storytelling project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Conor Dougherty
title: #CancelRent Is New Rallying Cry for Tenants. Landlords Are Alarmed.
description: From New York to Los Angeles, tenant groups are encouraging millions of renters to withhold May rent, which landlords warn would be devastating.
content: As unemployment soars across the country, tenants rights groups and community nonprofits have rallied around an audacious goal: to persuade the government to halt rent and mortgage payments — without back payments accruing — for as long as the economy is battered by the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Living With Loneliness
description: Plus, how to stay connected.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has forced many of us into isolation; now family gatherings and weekend brunches with friends are a thing of the past. While we’re all finding ways to cope — and maybe even trying to channel some optimism — living alone presents its own unique challenges (and possibly benefits too!).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Peed
title: Pride at the Plate for a Little League All-Star
description: In Phil Bildner’s “A High Five for Glenn Burke,” the inventor of the world’s most popular celebratory gesture helps a budding baseball player accept himself for who he is.
content: Fairly often one of my students raises a hand in class just as I’m saying something that feels important. When the palm hangs there, imploring but impertinent, I turn and ask, “You have a question, or you want a high-five?” The joke, however middling, cuts the tension. Almost always, the student replies, “Both.” We slap a high-five. The question is asked and answered. Class gets back to business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: Labs Across U.S. Join Federal Initiative to Study Coronavirus Genome
description: The project, announced by the C.D.C., will help trace patterns of transmission, investigate outbreaks and map how the virus is evolving, which can affect a cure.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday announced a national initiative to speed research into how the coronavirus was spreading around the country, bringing together at least 75 public health, academic and commercial institutions studying its genome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: A Life and Death Battle: 4 Days of Kidney Failure but No Dialysis
description: At the peak of the pandemic in New York, a longtime city employee joined a crush of patients in desperate need of treatment.
content: Orphaned as a youth in Bangladesh, Jamal Uddin worked in a ribbon factory in Lower Manhattan while attending high school, before graduating from college and ultimately finding a career helping people with H.I.V./AIDS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Sandra E. Garcia
title: Two Arrested in Killings of Transgender Women in Puerto Rico
description: The police said they had classified the deaths as a hate crime after the remains of two women were found in a badly burned car last week.
content: A week after the bodies of two transgender women were found in a badly burned car in Puerto Rico, the police said Thursday that they had arrested two men in connection with the killings and had turned them over to the F.B.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Tennis Coming Back Slowly With Exhibition Matches
description: The small-scale events could create a road map to help the men’s and women’s tours return.
content: Tennys Sandgren, who was on a roll before professional tennis shut down, has had enough of video games and self-isolation in his home near Nashville, Tenn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Tanzanian Cartoonist Has a Stick for Every Powerful Eye
description: Godfrey Mwampembwa, popularly known as Gado, has been holding politicians accountable for nearly 30 years. Now, his concern has shifted to the coronavirus.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — In a quiet office on the third floor of a building in Nairobi’s central business district, the cartoonist known by his pen name, Gado, was sketching a satire  about the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Congress Calls on Jeff Bezos of Amazon to Testify
description: Lawmakers want to question Mr. Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, as part of its antitrust investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — The House Judiciary Committee on Friday called on Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief executive, to testify before Congress, in a major escalation of its investigation into the country’s largest technology companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Blood Pressure Drugs Don’t Increase Coronavirus Risk, Studies Find
description: People taking widely used medicines did not face higher rates of infection or more severe illness, new research indicates.
content: Drugs that are widely prescribed to treat high blood pressure do not make patients more susceptible to coronavirus infection, or to severe illness if they do become infected, researchers reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Can Street Artists Survive a City in Lockdown?
description: Buskers, musicians and muralists have been entertaining London for centuries. But now the capital has gone quiet and the future of their activities looks uncertain.
content: LONDON — One recent Friday, Nathan Bowen, a graffiti artist, was spray painting a boarded-up storefront in East London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘Parks and Recreation’ Reunion: Isolate Yo’ Self
description: TV’s best best friends return in a sweet, goofy special that embodies the show’s philosophy: that community helps us survive.
content: The 2015 finale of “Parks and Recreation,” the NBC comedy set in a small-town bureaucracy, took place in the future. I would not suggest that you watch it right now. I say that not so much as a judgment of its quality but because its vision of the years it flash-forwarded to — from 2017 to 2048 — is, in retrospect, painfully optimistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Currid-Halkett
title: A Pandemic Isn’t a Reason to Abolish the SAT
description: For now, the SAT and ACT are more democratic than many of the other metrics used to evaluate college applicants.
content: Because of the threat posed by the coronavirus pandemic, the College Board, which administers the SAT and Advanced Placement exams, has canceled spring and summer testing and raised the possibility of offering SATs online in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Blue
title: A Shortage of Steak? Yes, and Ranchers Knew It Was Coming
description: The pandemic has laid bare the instability of the industrialized food chain.
content: PERKINS COUNTY, S.D. — I live on a ranch. When I stand on the gravel road that runs along the section line by my house I can look in any direction across the waving grass and, other than the modest huddle of buildings and fencing that compose our ranch, see little evidence of human development. To say it is remote is like saying water is wet. We aren’t Iowa remote or Wisconsin remote. This is the American steppe, where the population density is one person per square mile.
source.name: The New York Times

description: 21st century soccer is as much about the pursuit of style as success. But what defines what any of us find good to watch? And do we all have to enjoy the same thing?

title: Closing Number of a Musical
description: Trenton Charlson raises the curtain on our solving weekend.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This puzzle by Trenton Charlson is another Friday dazzler worth showing up for. Not only does it have a generous sprinkling of high-score Scrabble letters (just take a gander at the four Z’s in the northeast!), the entries are flashy and fun. The topics covered in the puzzle are plentiful, giving even a Friday-averse solver a chance at conquering it. And overall, the tone of the puzzle is cheery and optimistic, the perfect antidote to what we are all going through right now during the pandemic.

title: Fiona Ex Machina
description: Fiona Apple blows our minds, again.
content: “Fetch the Bolt Cutters” is Fiona Apple’s master class in channeling frustration and anger into what can only be called wisdom. Also, we hear from listeners all over the planet, sharing how they are taking care of the people in their lives.

author: By Galt Niederhoffer
title: How Coronavirus Shifted the Stakes of Teenage Rebellion
description: Living with an invisible outside threat, and no visible outlet, forced my daughter and me to negotiate and reconcile — and fast.
content: The weekend before New York City’s stay-at-home order went into effect, my 15-year-old daughter and I had an argument. She asked if she could hang out with friends in our neighborhood, promising to “be very careful” and “bring Purell.” Acknowledging the necessity of friends and fun, I said yes and sent her off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Donohue
title: The Big Impact of a Small Hobby
description: Drawing mundane things like my dish rack had helped me survive job loss. Could it be helping me through the coronavirus?
content: When I would tell people that drawing saved my life, I thought I was being hyperbolic. Then the coronavirus hit. Drawing had helped me survive another very dark period of my life, earlier. Could it now be helping me to stay healthy?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Parmesan! Crusted! Chicken!
description: Take those boneless chicken breasts and give them a crispy, cheesy exterior you won’t soon forget.
content: Welcome back to Five Weeknight Dishes. This week, I’ve been thinking about The Times’s original weeknight columnist, the French chef Pierre Franey, who wrote “60-Minute Gourmet.” (He pretty much invented boneless chicken breasts, and before chicken nuggets were a thing, he had us making goujonettes for dinner parties.) When he started in 1975, the ingredients available to most home cooks were pretty limited, as they are right now: a lot of dried, canned and frozen staples; the most basic fresh produce; and only the occasional fresh herbs or tomatoes or raspberries.

Beginning from his boyfriend’s apartment in Williamsburg, he heads north into Queens over the Pulaski Bridge and through Hunter’s Point South Park. title: How to Also Keep Your Car Healthy
description: Along with making medical equipment, the car industry is finding ways to keep their customers safer, like coming to you when your car needs service.
content: The response of the auto industry in times of national peril is legendary. Detroit’s reputation as the Arsenal of Democracy, producing the tens of thousands of bombers and tanks that helped the Allies win World War II, is well-deserved.

author: By Adam Grant
title: Job Interviews Are Broken. There’s a Way to Fix Them.
description: Instead of focusing on credentials, let’s give candidates the chance to showcase their will and skill to learn.
content: Within the first few minutes of the interview, I knew the candidate was a bad fit for a sales position. His résumé had tipped me off: He was a math major and built robots in his spare time. Now we were sitting face-to-face in my office, but he hardly made any eye contact. When I told my boss I wasn’t going to hire him because of that, she said, “You know this is a phone sales job, right?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Zev Buffman, 89, Prolific Producer From Broadway to Florida, Dies
description: In his long career, he persuaded Elizabeth Taylor to make her Broadway debut in “The Little Foxes” and produced a memorable flop starring Muhammad Ali.
content: Zev Buffman had been a prominent Broadway producer for two decades when he met Elizabeth Taylor in 1980 at the opening night of his revival of “Brigadoon,” the Lerner and Loewe musical, at the National Theater in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Drive-Throughs Are Now a Lifeline for Fast-Food Chains
description: With dine-in restaurants shuttered and social distancing paramount, drive-throughs are now providing a crucial source of revenue during the pandemic.
content: For decades, the fast-food drive-through has been a greasy symbol of Americana, a roadside ritual for millions of travelers with a hankering for burgers and fries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lovia Gyarkye
title: ‘All Day and a Night’ Review: Growth Behind Bars
description: In this drama from one of the screenwriters of “Black Panther,” a young man embarks on a journey of belated self-discovery.
content: In the early moments of “All Day and a Night,” a gut-wrenching drama now streaming on Netflix, comes an emotional courtroom scene. Jahkor Lincoln (Ashton Sanders) sits with a look of stoic resignation in a room packed with the loved ones of the two people he has murdered. Before the judge delivers Jahkor’s life sentence, the mother of one of the deceased stands to speak. “My granddaughter is only 10 years old,” she says. “You took away her whole family and never even given a reason why. That’s all I want to know. Why?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Jane Gottlieb
title: An Upstate N.Y. Backlash Over Virus Shutdown: ‘It’s Not Up Here’
description: Vast swaths of upstate are largely untouched by the pandemic, and some residents are more worried about the economy than about their health.
content: HERKIMER, N.Y. — Scott Tranter knows how deeply the coronavirus has affected New York, with 300,000 people testing positive in the state, 18,000 dead and the economy shut down.

title: U.K. Virus Tests Surpass Target, but Britain’s Deaths May Overtake Italy’s
description: There was good news and bad news for Britons on Friday in the statistical barometers of the pandemic, which experts say have become an understandable but misplaced fixation in the country.
content: LONDON — For Britons looking to judge their government’s desperate response to the coronavirus pandemic, the verdict has increasingly come down to two numbers: 100,000, the number of tests that officials promised to conduct every day by the end of April; and 27,510, the latest death toll.

title: Farewell to the Friendly Cheek Kiss
description: The moratorium on “la bise,” as it’s known in France, brings sorrow, but also relief.
content: I never meant to kiss Miuccia Prada. Not on the lips, anyway. It was a muggy afternoon in the spring of 2015, and I was in Tokyo at the opening of her new Miu Miu store. I had been waiting in line to congratulate her. The lights above me hung bright and hot, and I knew without looking that I had sweated through the tailored suit I’d been given to wear for the occasion. A famous French actress stood two people ahead of me at the front of the line. Her arms Pietà’d out as she approached the Italian designer, hands landing confidently on Mrs. Prada’s shoulders, and, as if tracing the line of a toppled-over parabola, she kissed her — mwah — on the left cheek, and then again — mwah — on the right. The next person followed suit, making it through the exchange without incident. Then it was my turn. I kind of cranked forward and cupped Mrs. Prada’s waist the way a high school junior might initiate a slow dance. Then I lurched even closer, barely grazing one side of her cheek on the first try. On the second, determined this time to make contact, I touched the hinge of her lips to mine.

content: The annual summer Food & Wine Classic in Aspen, Colo., has been canceled. But the New York City Wine and Food Festival, a four-day fall fund-raiser that sprawls across the city in restaurants and event spaces? Not so fast. Lee Schrager, the organizer and founder is going digital with it, starting this week, and still hopes the festival will return in October. (He was able to slip in the South Beach edition in Miami just under the wire in February.) Now with the gala atmosphere at tastings, lunches, cocktail gatherings and dinners falling victim to social distancing, the festival has added NYCWFF at Home, with sessions, mainly classes, featuring food celebrities and chefs a few times a week. Participants, up to 300 per session, pay $20 each and can join via Zoom. There will even be a 15-minute Q. and A. at the end of each event. All the money goes to the National Restaurant Association’s Restaurant Employee Relief Fund. First up on Monday at 2:30 p.m. will be Neil Patrick Harris cooking with his husband, David Burtka; Wednesday will feature Alex Guarnaschelli and her daughter. Plans are for it to continue for months to come.
